commit.message:
Add missing header tags as per the spec (PR #1238)

Add omitted tags to KNOWN_HEADER_FIELDS and VALID_HEADER_ORDER, so that
AlignmentHeader.from_dict()/to_dict() will preserve all header field tags
defined in the SAM specification. Addresses #1237.

Exercise TP:linear in some header tests.

Co-authored-by: John Marshall <jmarshall@hey.com>

Add missing header tags as per the spec (PR #1238)

Add omitted tags to KNOWN_HEADER_FIELDS and VALID_HEADER_ORDER, so that
AlignmentHeader.from_dict()/to_dict() will preserve all header field tags
defined in the SAM specification. Addresses #1237.

Exercise TP:linear in some header tests.

Co-authored-by: John Marshall <jmarshall@hey.com>

commit.message: Update actions to use Python 3.12 final and latest actions/checkout

Use relative cimports rather than luck

Previously these imports found their targets because setup.py's
get_pysam_version() adds "pysam/" to sys.path. This made them work
for building pysam but not in the unlikely case of external use.

Bump version number to 0.22.0 and add release notes

Add handover message from Andreas, and add John to various lists
of authors. Update copyright years in doc/conf.py.
Merge Cirrus CI-based release workflow revamp

Build ARM Linux and macOS wheels natively on Cirrus CI

Add .cirrus.yml workflow that runs natively on ARM macOS/Linux.
For Linux, this is faster than building via emulation. For macOS,
this is more correct, as cross-compiling was producing unusable
wheels! It turns out we are building libhts.a incorrectly when
cross-compiling: see #1231.

Remove ARM builds from the x86_64 release.yaml GH Actions workflow.
Also remove i686 builds: it's unclear whether these were being built
correctly either, and probably very few people use them.

Update to the very recently released current cibuildwheel, which
updates to the also very recently released Python 3.12.0 (final).

Clean libhts.a between wheels and simplify URL

Add before-build command to clean htslib/*.o and libhts.a before building
each wheel, as these are in the source directory and would otherwise be
reused (possibly for a different architecture!). Eventually we will
configure htslib out-of-tree within build_temp or perhaps build_platlib,
i.e., under build/, and will be able to remove this as build/ is known
to the Python infrastructure and automatically managed.

Simplify documentation URL, as we have switched our RTD default from
latest to stable.

Add release dates to NEWS / release notes

Use ..rubric:: to add a subtitle showing the release date for releases
going back a couple of years. (Rubric works reasonably well for this,
though the vertical spacing leaves a little to be desired.)
Merge release workflow revamp and package metadata updates

Update package description metadata

Wordsmith the long description, add CRAM to the list of formats,
move the URLs to project.urls so they appear in the PyPI sidebar,
and specify the content type (to avoid twine warnings).

Wordsmith the (short) description and ensure it is the same in setup()
and pyproject.toml. Make pyproject.toml's version entry dynamic instead
of duplicating the canonical value in pysam/version.py.

Use Trusted Publisher flow to upload to PyPI

Set up pypi and testpypi environments within the pysam GitHub repo,
and set up the repo as a Trusted Publisher at PyPI and TestPyPI.

Update the upload_pypi job accordingly, selecting between the
environments and using TestpyPI for all pushes (not just tags).

Update to current cibuildwheel, which updates to Python 3.12.0rc3.
Shorten and remove workflow/job names, which improves how they appear
on status web pages.

Backport htslib/kseq.h parsing performance improvement (PR #1227)

Apply the main part of PR samtools/htslib#1674. Pysam does use kseq itself,
so it is worth applying this now without waiting for the next HTSlib release
to be imported.

Co-Authored-By: Fabian Klötzl <fabian@kloetzl.info>

Backport htslib/kseq.h parsing performance improvement (PR #1227)

Apply the main part of PR samtools/htslib#1674. Pysam does use kseq itself,
so it is worth applying this now without waiting for the next HTSlib release
to be imported.

Co-Authored-By: Fabian Klötzl <fabian@kloetzl.info>

commit.message:
Clarify AlignedSegment.get_reference_positions() documentation

Explain the circumstances under which positions and entries are omitted
from the returned list, clarify full_length, and mention the related
get_aligned_pairs(); fixes #838. Clarify positions are 0-based; fixes #836.

Update CI badge to show GitHub Actions CI status

We moved away from TravisCI rather a while ago.

Include NEWS from doc/release.rst and link issues/PRs

Remove doc/release.rst's duplicate copy of the release notes, instead
including NEWS via a reStructuredText include directive. This means
that NEWS needs to be valid reStructuredText, but it mostly already is.

Install a Sphinx 7.2.5+ include-read hook that expands plain `PR #NNN`
and `#NNN` references in the NEWS file into role syntax that the extlinks
extension can expand into links to pysam issues/PRs at the GitHub repo.

Bring NEWS into sync with doc/release.rst

Set off nested bullets with blank lines, as reStructuredText requires.

Drop dotfiles from archives and C files from statistics

Add a .gitattributes file listing files that should be ignored
by `git archive` and ignoring the imported htslib/samtools/bcftools
code for the purposes of GitHub's language use statistics.

Add bespoke cp38-manylinux2014_x86_64 wheel for Ubuntu 20.04

Build an extra wheel for use with Ubuntu 20.04's system Python 3.8
and pip 20.0.2, which can use manylinux2014 at best.

Refactor pysam wheel building

Redesign job matrix to build x86+ARM macOS wheels in one job, and
i686+x86_64+ARM Linux wheels in principle in one job -- but subdivide
by Python version because each emulated ARM build takes 1.5 hours.
(Whereas ARM macOS builds are fast because they are cross-compiled.)

No need to set up Python or prerequisites outside cibuildwheel.
Use a separate script to install prerequisites regardless of the
package manager in use. Use CIBW_* variables carefully so that the
same job step handles both Linux and macOS.

Update cibuildwheel, and ensure we build a complete set of wheels
from cp36 to the upcoming cp312.

Handle MD:Z and MD:A types in build_alignment_sequence()

Check the type code and raise TypeError instead of segfaulting if it is
not a Z string. Also accept MD:A to work around HTSeq bug that writes
1-character strings as MD:A:v. Fixes #1226. Add tests.

Revert setuptools version requirement back to v59.0

It turns out that the last setuptools available for Python 3.6
is v59.6.0. So if we want to build py36 wheels, we need to reduce
the setuptools requirement back to v59 or thereabouts.
Merge setup(requires=) removal and Cython<4 req (PR #1219)

Mention that `pip install` will usually use a wheel

...and that configuring via $HTSLIB_CONFIGURE_OPTIONS etc only applies
when installing from an sdist. Fixes #1086.

Reinstate distutils.errors fallback

While pyproject.toml specifies a version of setuptools that does
provide LinkError et al, our CI uses `python setup.py build` without
constraints so can use an already installed setuptools that may be
an earlier version. For example, py38 tries to use v56.0.0.

For now, reinstate the fallback to work around this.

Limit current pysam to Cython 3.x avoiding eventual 4.0 (PR #1218)

If there is ever a Cython 4 release, the major version number bump will
be due to some incompatible change. While we fully plan to support such a
Cython version in the contemporaneous future pysam, today's releases may
not be compatible with it. Mark them as such -- to be revisited during
such a Cython's development cycle and pre-releases. Fixes #1217.

Remove obsolete setup() `requires` entry (adapted from PR #1216)

Unlike install_requires and setup_requires, it seems that this no longer
really does anything. It adds a `Requires: cython (>=0.29.12)` line to
the resulting wheel's pysam-x.y.z.dist-info/METADATA file, but that's
a v1.1 item that was superseded in 2005. As pyproject.toml specifies
the requirement anyway, we can just delete this.

Now that we depend on settings in pyproject.toml, update the setuptools
requirement to v61.0.0, which is documented as the version that introduced
robust pyproject.toml support.

The distutils.errors fallback was already unnecessary with a requirement
for setuptools >= v59.0.0, so remove it.

Co-Authored-By: John Marshall <jmarshall@hey.com>

Move tox settings to pyproject.toml & remove .python-version

Collect settings in pyproject.toml instead of bespoke files. (Eventually
we may render setup.cfg unnecessary too.) Fix list syntax and set REF_PATH
environment variable to speed up running pytest by avoiding network CRAM
reference requests.

Remove .python-version, which was probably inadvertently added. Ignore it
and tidy up ignoring Sphinx output.

Backport htscodecs improvement: Check for HWCAP_ASIMD

Apply part of PR samtools/htscodecs#91. The manylinux2014_aarch64 image
is based on CentOS 7 and uses glibc 2.17, while these aarch64 capability
bits were added in v2.24. We'll build aarch64 wheels on manylinux_2_28
but might as well ensure manylinux2014 builds too.

Really fix macOS config_vars hackery

Attempting to alter sysconfig's own config_vars, so that build_ext
initialisation would see the new value, did not always work; e.g. it
failed with Python 3.6 via cibuildwheel.

Instead override it properly in cy_build_ext.run(). The LDSHARED
environment variable, if set, is used by build_ext.run()'s compiler
initialisation to override the (unaltered) sysconfig setting.

(Omit SHLIB_EXT, which is unused in setuptools/distutils/cython.)

Explicitly select sphinx_rtd_theme and update Sphinx

Update to Sphinx 7.x now that there is a sphinx_rtd_theme release
that supports it. Update MANIFEST.in and remove duplicate entries.
